question.title: How to create a set order for a HashSet (Java 24, IntelliJ Community)
question.body:
I have been working on a simple clicker game, and I am using HashSet to store the list of achievements, and they aren't showing up in order. I understand that HashSet does not work like this, but using other data methods does not seem to work as well. How can I order this HashSet so that the achievements show up in order?

import javax.swing.*;
import java.awt.*;
import java.util.HashSet;

public class AchievementManager {
    public AchievementManager(GamePanel panel, Stats stats) {
        this.panel = panel;
        this.stats = stats;
    }

    public void setAchievementPanel(JPanel panel) {
        this.achievementPanel = panel;
    }
    GamePanel panel;
    Stats stats;
    HashSet<String> unlockedAchievements = new HashSet<>();
    HashSet<String> allAchievements = new HashSet<>();
    {
        allAchievements.add("coin10");
        allAchievements.add("coin500");
        allAchievements.add("coin1000000");
        allAchievements.add("click50");
        allAchievements.add("click250");
        allAchievements.add("click1000");
    }
    private JPanel achievementPanel;

    public void unlock(String id){
        if(!unlockedAchievements.contains(id)){
            unlockedAchievements.add(id);
            panel.updateAchievements(id, true);
            panel.createPopupPanel(panel.getMainFrame(), format(id));
            createNewButton(id, true);
        }
    }

    public void achievementCheck(){
        if(stats.getMoney() >= 10 && !unlockedAchievements.contains("coin10")){
            unlock("coin10");
        }
        if(stats.getMoney() >= 500 && !unlockedAchievements.contains("coin500")){
            unlock("coin500");
        }
        if(stats.getMoney() >= 1000000 && !unlockedAchievements.contains("coins1000000")){
            unlock("coin1000000");
        }
        if(stats.getTotalClicks() >= 50 && !unlockedAchievements.contains("click50")){
            unlock("click50");
        }
        if(stats.getTotalClicks() >= 250 && !unlockedAchievements.contains("click250")){
            unlock("click250");
        }
        if(stats.getTotalClicks() >= 1000 && !unlockedAchievements.contains("click1000")){
            unlock("click1000");
        }
    }

    public String format(String id){
        switch(id) {
            case ("coin10"):
                return "Reached 10 Coins";

            case ("coin500"):
                return "Reached 500 Coins";

            case ("coin1000000"):
                return "Reached 1M Coins";

            case ("click50"):
                return "Clicked 50 Times";

            case ("click250"):
                return "Clicked 250 Times";

            case ("click1000"):
                return "Clicked 1000 Times";
        }
        return id;
    }

    public void createNewButton(String id, boolean unlocked) {
        if (achievementPanel == null) {
            System.err.println("Achievement panel not set!");
            return;
        }

        JButton newAchievement = new JButton(format(id));
        newAchievement.setFont(FontLoader.customFont.deriveFont(15f));
        newAchievement.setAlignmentX(Component.CENTER_ALIGNMENT);
        newAchievement.setFocusable(false);

        if (unlocked) {
            newAchievement.setBackground(new Color(46, 204, 113)); // Green
        } else {
            newAchievement.setBackground(Color.LIGHT_GRAY); // Gray
        }

        achievementPanel.add(newAchievement);
    }



    public void reset(){
        unlockedAchievements.clear();
    }
}

Part of GamePanel.java

public void openAchievementMenu() {
        JWindow achievementWindow = new JWindow();



        // Main container panel
        JPanel mainPanel = new JPanel();
        mainPanel.setLayout(new BoxLayout(mainPanel, BoxLayout.Y_AXIS));
        mainPanel.setBorder(BorderFactory.createCompoundBorder(
                BorderFactory.createLineBorder(new Color(0, 0, 150), 5),
                BorderFactory.createEmptyBorder(10, 10, 10, 10)
        ));

        // Top bar with close button
        JPanel topBar = new JPanel(new BorderLayout());
        topBar.setMaximumSize(new Dimension(Integer.MAX_VALUE, 30));
        topBar.setBackground(new Color(46, 204, 113));

        JLabel title = new JLabel("Achievements");
        title.setFont(FontLoader.customFont.deriveFont(25f));
        topBar.add(title, BorderLayout.CENTER);

        JButton closeButton = new JButton("X");
        closeButton.setBackground(new Color(24, 73, 195));
        closeButton.setFocusable(false);
        closeButton.setFocusPainted(false);
        closeButton.addActionListener(e -> achievementWindow.dispose());
        topBar.add(closeButton, BorderLayout.EAST);

        mainPanel.add(topBar);
        mainPanel.add(Box.createVerticalStrut(10));

        // Achievements list
        achievementPanel = new JPanel();
        achievementPanel.setLayout(new BoxLayout(achievementPanel, BoxLayout.Y_AXIS));
        achievementPanel.setAlignmentX(Component.CENTER_ALIGNMENT);

        achievementManager.setAchievementPanel(achievementPanel);


        int totalAchievements = achievementManager.allAchievements.size();
        int unlockedAchievements = achievementManager.unlockedAchievements.size();

        java.util.List<String> reversedList = new java.util.ArrayList<>(achievementManager.allAchievements);
        Collections.reverse(reversedList);

        for (String achievement : reversedList) {
            boolean isUnlocked = achievementManager.unlockedAchievements.contains(achievement);
            achievementManager.createNewButton(achievement, isUnlocked);
        }

        mainPanel.add(achievementPanel);
        mainPanel.add(Box.createVerticalGlue());

        // Add main panel to window
        achievementWindow.getContentPane().add(mainPanel);
        achievementWindow.setSize(300, 400);
        achievementWindow.setLocationRelativeTo(null); // Center
        achievementWindow.setVisible(true);
        achievementWindow.setAlwaysOnTop(true);
    }

I tried using a String array, and I expected it to work, but I found that HashSet was more efficient.

answers.body:
The JDK has two good options, dependning on what exactly you mean by "in order".

First, you have a LinkedHashSet, which will retain the order of insertion.

Second, if in fact by "in order" you mean "sorted", you could use a TreeSet.

question_comments.body: "was more efficient"? Without satisfying the requirement(s), that is, without maintaining the order? I would not call that efficient... doing nothing at all will be even the most efficient (no time consumption)
If you have a fixed number of achievements you can use an enum and EnumSet which is very fast and has a defined order

"but I found that HashSet was more efficent" - if you're really only looking through a small number of things, just how efficient do you need it to be? Wouldn't you rather have something that works the way that you wanted it to but took a microsecond or two longer to get the right answer, than something that gives you the wrong answer quicker? (I suspect a list of some form would be better than an array, but that's a different matter...)
